questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of innate immunity?

choices.text: Made of epithelial barriers, phagocytes, innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) and NK cells
Has a lag phase between exposure and response

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Has a lag phase between exposure and response.

Explanation:

The lag phase between exposure and response is not a feature of innate immunity as it acts rapidly against pathogens.

  • The lag phase is a feature of adaptive immunity. It specifically targets the pathogen causing infection, so it first needs to recognize the pathogen. This means that it’s slower to respond than the innate immune system, but it’s more accurate when it does respond.
  • Because of immunological memory, the next time it faces the same pathogen, there is a quick and robust response.
  • Innate immunity is the body's first line of defense against pathogens, present since birth. It responds similarly to all germs and foreign substances, hence the term non-specific immune system.

Difference between innate and acquired immunity

Innate/native immunity

Acquired/adaptive immunity

Present since birth (Option A)

Occurs after exposure to the pathogen

Quick, non-specific response (Option C)

Slower, specific response to a pathogen

No immunological memory

Has immunological memory

Examples include :

  • Epithelial barriers like skin, GIT. (Option B)
  • Plasma proteins like C-reactive protein.
  • Neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, complement.

Cells are of 2 types :

  • B lymphocytes: Provides humoral immunity and produces antibodies
  • 2. T lymphocytes: Involved in cell-mediated immunity and help with immunity against intracellular microbes

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes. He is diagnosed with a viral infection. Which of the following cells is most likely involved in the early defense against the offending agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NK cells

Explanation:

In this scenario, the patient has a viral infection, and the body's initial defense mechanism against the virus is Natural Killer (NK) cells.

Natural Killer cell (NK) :

  • Produced by a large granular lymphocyte.
  • Constitutes 5 to 10% of circulating blood lymphocytes.
  • Function:
    • It can be part of both innate and adaptive immunity.
    • Innate immunity:
    • Directly kill the virus-infected cells or tumour cells.
    • Adaptive immunity:
    • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

 

T cells (Option B) are important in the adaptive immune response against viruses, they are not typically involved in the body's immediate defense mechanism during the early stages of infection.

Macrophages and Histiocytes (Option C & D) are part of the innate immune system and play a role in the immune response to viral infections. However, NK cells are more directly involved in the early defence against viruses due to their ability to recognize and kill virus-infected cells without prior sensitization.

questions.text: A 20-year-old medical student went for a screening health test and was injected with PPD intradermally. Identify the immune cell in the skin that picks up the PPD to present it to T cells.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Langerhans cells

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario describes the Mantoux test. Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa. They are responsible for antigen presentation in the immune system. They are part of the body's first line of defense and belong to the innate immune system.

Dendritic cells(DC) are the most potent antigen-presenting cells(APC) for initiating T-cell responses against protein antigens.

Dendritic cell properties:

  • They have many cytoplasmic processes resembling dendrites and receptors that sense microbes and cell damage that stimulate the secretion of cytokines. This has a critical role in inflammation and antiviral defense.
  • They express receptors for capturing antigens, including TLRs and lectins.
  • They are located under the epithelia and interstitia of all tissues, which are common sites for capturing antigens.
  • They have a higher concentration of MHCs and are present in greater numbers in the epidermis than other APCs. Immature DCs within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells.

Langhans cells/Langhans giant cells (Option A) are multinucleated giant cells found in granulomas. They consist of huge cytoplasm and multiple nuclei that are derived from the fusion of multiple activated macrophages.

Follicular dendritic cells (Option B) are specialized cells found in lymphoid follicles within lymph nodes and the spleen. They play a crucial role in presenting antigens to B cells and are involved in the formation and maintenance of the germinal center reaction.

NK cells (Option D) are not APCs. They destroy abnormal cells, such as virus-infected or malignant cells.

questions.text: Toll-like receptors are seen in which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a family of pattern-recognition receptors expressed on immune cells like macrophages, dendritic cells, and natural killer cells, as well as on non-immune cells like endothelial cells.

Pattern recognition receptors

Receptor Type

Cellular Compartment

Function

Toll-like Receptors (TLRs)

Plasma membrane, endosomal vesicles

Detect microbial components (e.g., bacterial lipopolysaccharides, viral RNA)

The final effect of antigen binding to TLR is the activation of transcription factors:

1. NF-κB: Stimulates the synthesis and secretion of cytokines and expression of adhesion molecules.

2. Interferon regulatory factors (IRFs): stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines and interferons.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought with complaints of fever and burning micturition. She was diagnosed to have UTI with toxin-producing strains of E.coli. Where are blood-borne antigens trapped in the immune response to these toxins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spleen

Explanation:

In the immune response to toxin-producing strains of E. coli causing UTI, blood-borne antigens are primarily trapped and processed in the spleen.

  • The spleen is an important secondary lymphoid organ where circulating antigens, including those derived from bacteria and their toxins, are captured by specialized cells such as macrophages.
  • These antigens are then presented to immune cells, initiating an immune response to neutralize the toxins and clear the infection.
  • The spleen is part of the secondary lymphoid organs, including lymph nodes and mucosal/cutaneous lymphoid tissues.
  • They are a part of adaptive immunity.
  • In contrast, primary lymphoid organs like the thymus and bone marrow are involved in the development and maturation of immune cells (T and B lymphocytes).

questions.text: Which of the following HLA gene regions encodes Class II MHC molecules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HLA-D

Explanation:

Class II MHC molecules are encoded in a region called HLA-D.

Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) is derived from the HLA gene that is presented on chromosome 6p.

HLA consists of three regions, which have been designated as class I, class II, and class III based on the structure and function of gene products.

Gene region

Encoded products

Class I
  • HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Class II
  • HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Class III
  • Tumor necrosis factor (TNF), complement and heat shock proteins

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever and loose stool for one week. He was diagnosed with typhoid infection. Which of the following MHC class is responsible for antigen presentation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class II

Explanation:

In a patient with typhoid infection (caused by Salmonella typhi), antigen presentation primarily involves MHC class II molecules, which present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to activate an immune response.

Class I

MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens derived from intracellular pathogens, such as viruses and some bacteria.

Class II

MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens derived from extracellular pathogens, such as Salmonella typhi, the bacterium responsible for typhoid fever.

Class III

MHC class III molecules are not involved in antigen presentation. They encode components of the complement system and other immune-related molecules.

Non-MHC-dependent antigen presentation

While non-MHC-dependent antigen presentation can occur through mechanisms like CD1 molecules presenting lipid antigens.
  • Class II MHC molecules are expressed on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs), such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells.
  • These cells process exogenous antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins after internalization into endosomes or lysosomes.
  • The internalized proteins are broken down into peptides and associated with class II MHC in the vesicles and transported to the cell surface as stable peptide-MHC complexes.
  • The class II-peptide complex is recognized by CD4+/helper T cells.


Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to CD4+ helper T cells, initiating an immune response.

questions.text: Which component functions as the antigen binding site in MHC complexes 1 and 2, respectively?

choices.text: MHC 1 - beta microglobulin; MCH 2 - alpha 3 domain
MHC 1 - alpha 1 and 2; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and beta 1
MHC 1 - alpha 1 and beta 1; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and 2
MHC 1 - invariant chain; MHC 2 - beta microglobulin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MHC 1 - alpha 1 and 2; MHC 2 - alpha 1 and beta 1

Explanation:

In MHC class I molecules, the alpha 1 and beta 1 domains together form the antigen-binding site, which binds to peptides derived from intracellular proteins.

  • MHC-1 molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells, antigen-presenting cells, and platelets
  • Mature RBCs that lack a nucleus don't express MHC-1
  • They are heterodimers with a polymorphic α or heavy chain linked non-covalently to a smaller β2-microglobulin.
  • The antigen is bound within a groove between the α1 and α2 domains of the alpha chain.
  • This, along with the β2-microglobulin, forms a stable complex to be displayed on the cell surface.

In MHC class II molecules, similar to MHC class I, the antigen-binding site is also formed by the alpha 1 and beta 1 domains, binding peptides derived from extracellular proteins presented by antigen-presenting cells.

  • They consist of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains of equal length.
  • The invariant chain is a protein structure associated with MHC-2. It is associated with MHC-2 within endosomes to prevent the binding of endogenous antigens. The invariant chain is later broken down, while MHC-2 is moved to the cell surface.

questions.text: A newborn delivered by a mother who received no prenatal care is being evaluated. On examination, the baby has severe oedema, icterus, and organomegaly and is in respiratory distress. What immunoglobulin class was responsible for this child’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgG

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario describes Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), also known as erythroblastosis fetalis, occurs when there is an incompatibility between the blood types of a mother and her fetus.

  • This condition is often caused by Rh (Rhesus) blood group incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive. During pregnancy, maternal antibodies of the IgG class against the Rh antigen can cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells (RBCs), leading to hemolysis (destruction of RBCs) in the fetus.
  • This results in various degrees of anaemia and potentially severe complications for the newborn.
  • This crossing is facilitated by active transplacental transfer mechanisms, primarily mediated by syncytiotrophoblast cells expressing neonatal Fc receptors (FcRn). These receptors interact with the Fc domain of IgG, permitting their transfer.
  • This phenomenon is also responsible for newborns' passive immunity, with IgG being the most abundant antibody in their circulation.


 

IgM (Option A) are multinucleated giant cells found in granulomas. They consist of huge cytoplasm and multiple nuclei that are derived from the fusion of multiple activated macrophages. It cannot cross the placenta due to its large size (pentameric structure).

IgD and IgE (Option C and D) are also incapable of crossing the placenta.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. He is diagnosed with pneumonia. Which of the following cytokines is most likely to be elevated in this patient due to the activation of classical macrophages in response to the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Interleukin- 1

Explanation:

Interleukin-1 will be elevated in this patient due to the activation of classical macrophages in response to the infection.

The two main pathways of macrophage function are classical (M1) and alternative (M2) pathways, each driven by different stimuli and resulting in different macrophage functions.

 

Stimuli

Functions and Secretions

Role

Classical (M1) Activation

Microbial products (e.g., LPS), IFN-γ

Pro-inflammatory and microbicidal functions: NO, lysosomal enzymes, TNF-α, IL-1, IL-12, IL-23
  • Host defense
  • Microbial destruction
  • Inflammation

Alternative (M2) Activation

IL-4, IL-13 (Option C)

Tissue repair, resolution of inflammation, secretion of TGF-β, growth factors, IL-10
  • Tissue remodeling
  • Angiogenesis, Immunoregulation
  • Wound healing
  • Tissue repair and homeostasis

Interleukin-2 (IL-2) (Option B) aka T-cell growth factor is a cytokine with pleiotropic effects on the immune system and is not associated with classical macrophage activation.

Interleukin-10 (IL-10) (Option D) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine released from alternatively activated macrophages.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with a history of eating sand. His stool examination showed Ascaris eggs. What type of T-cell is responsible for dealing with this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) TH2 cells

Explanation:

TH2 cells (CD4+) are responsible for dealing with helminthic (parasitic) infections.

Five major CD4 T helper cell (TH) subsets have been identified: TH1, TH2, TH17, Treg (T regulatory), and Tfh (follicular T helper) cells.

Subtype

Function and Characteristics

Key Cytokines

TH1

(Option A)
  • Involved in chronic inflammatory diseases. Activated by IL-12 from APCs. Secrete IFN-gamma, activating macrophages.
  • Stimulates macrophages to form epithelioid cells and giant cells.

IFN-gamma

TH2
  • Responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation. Release cytokines IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13.
  • To expel parasites from the body, stimulate eosinophil activation, antibody production (especially IgE), and mucus production.

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

TH17

(Option C)
  • Defend against extracellular bacteria and fungi. Secrete IL-17 and IL-22, attracting neutrophils and monocytes.

IL-17, IL-22

Treg (T regulatory)

(Option D)
  • Suppresses immune response, maintains homeostasis and self-tolerance.
  • Inhibit T cell proliferation and cytokine production, preventing autoimmune reaction.

IL-10, TGF-beta

Tfh (Follicular T helper)
  • Assist B cells in rapid proliferation and antibody production.
  • Help produce antibodies with greater affinity.

IL-21
